title: Ground Zero Ceremony Marks 18th Anniversary of 9/11 Attacks
text:
Beth Battista placed a rose at the inscribed name of her brother-in-law, Peter Carroll, at the 9/11 Memorial in New York on Wednesday.

NEW YORK— Marjorie Miller returns often to the place where her husband died, now a memorial of black stone and falling water. But it is on the anniversary of his death that she is most drawn to the site where two 110-story towers stood until Sept. 11, 2001.

“Every year I feel compelled to come,” she said Wednesday in lower Manhattan on the 18th anniversary of the worst terrorist attacks on U.S. soil. Joel Miller and nearly 3,000 others died at the World Trade Center, the Pentagon and in a field near Shanksville, Pa., when terrorists commandeered four jetliners and turned them into weapons.

Mr. Miller’s remains, like those of many victims, were never recovered.

“In many ways this is our cemetery,” Ms. Miller said. “To me, this is his place, and this is my place. He breathed here, he died here. This is where I feel him.”

Ms. Miller and thousands of others attended a ceremony at the Ground Zero memorial site that began just before 9 a.m., with moments of silence and the ringing of bells to mark when planes hit the World Trade Center and when the twin towers fell. Mr. Miller had been at work at Marsh & McLennan on the 94th floor when the first plane hit his tower.

As with previous anniversaries at the 9/11 Memorial, the names of the nearly 3,000 victims killed in the attacks were read by family and friends.

Ceremonies were held in New York City and Washington, D.C., to commemorate the 18th anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. Photo: Jane Lane/EPA/Shutterstock

In Washington, President Trump and the first lady participated in a moment of silence on the South Lawn of the White House at 8:46 a.m. to mark the time at which the first plane struck the north tower of the World Trade Center. Mr. Trump later headed to the Pentagon, where he recalled the day 18 years ago, describing the attack as “seared into our soul.” He praised first responders, offered support to families who lost loved ones and promised to respond to any future threats with military might.

Mr. Trump cited first responder Cyril “Rick” Rescorla in his remarks. The president said he would posthumously award the Presidential Citizens Medal to Mr. Rescorla, who as first vice president of security at Morgan Stanley on 9/11 helped thousands of fellow workers escape.

For many of the loved ones of the victims, time hasn’t eased their pain.

La-Shawn Clark was one of the dozens of relatives who took part in reading the victims’ names on Wednesday at the ceremony in lower Manhattan. Her husband of 15 years, Benjamin Keefe Clark, was a chef for Fiduciary Trust and died trying to get people out of one of the towers when it collapsed.

She was thinking of all the milestones he has missed from their five children, especially their first grandchild, a girl, due Oct. 7.

“This one is kind of hard,” she said, through tears.

description: Thousands of people attended a ceremony at the Ground Zero memorial site in lower Manhattan to mark the 18th anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.
